hobby.message: Any luck fixing the old typewriter?
Any new mods on your FPV quad?
Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Still. Maybe not as much space to do it properly.
Haven't been out flying my drone much lately.
Not worth pushing it now, with all the curfews.
Best to keep hobbies quiet for a while.
Still breathing. Can't say the same for my drone batteries.
Used to practice FPV flying after work—haven't risked it much lately.
Patrols are everywhere now. Even old spots are watched.
Curfews kind of kill the mood.
Miss the rush, honestly.
Yeah, still breathing. Barely, with all this lockdown.
Got an FPV drone hobby—usually fly in the off-grid zones.
Last weekend, patrols caught me near Sector 19.
Had to ditch the quad and run, first time ever.
Not the fun kind of adrenaline.
Might lay low a while now.
Breathing and flying, barely. My drone keeps me sane after shifts.
Used to hit abandoned machine halls, old conveyors, no cameras.
Since Directorate’s curfews, every spot’s risky. More patrols, zero blind zones.
Saturday, I almost lost my quad escaping a sweep.
No feeds, no goggles—pure guesswork.
Reminds me what a blackout feels like.
But that flight, short as it was—worth every second.
Surviving, thanks to my drone habit. Freestyle FPV—it’s my way out.
Started years back, before BCI tracked which air you breathed.
Now, I find dead zones—industrial shells, no sensors working. It’s real freedom.
Patrols force you to fly in blackout. Ghost signals only, full manual.
Last week I almost got nabbed, ducked out through the conveyors.
Feels like we’re shrinking, squeezed tighter every season.
Used to joke the city was a circuit—now it’s just a loop.
Still, for a minute, up in the dark with the quad, world fell away.
hobby_answer: Analog. Digital's too noisy lately.
Haven't flown much since the curfews started.
Too many patrols now, not worth the risk.
Machines in the old sector pick up signals these days.
Mostly just keep the gear maintained. That's it.
Analog, but signal's glitchy with Directorate interference.
Hard to even find safe spots after the new curfews.
Most industrial dead zones are on patrol routes now.
Fly time's maybe ten minutes if lucky.
Lately, it's mostly building and testing—less flying.
Still analog—old habits, less visible.
Sector 19's about the only place with dead air now.
Patrols doubled since the crackdown, so everything's fast and quiet.
Had to cut a session short last week when boots showed up.
The city's gotten tighter, less space for anything off-grid.
Feels like even the stray frequencies are being watched.
Hard to find that feeling of freedom anymore.
Analog for most flights—digital bands are too mapped now.
Rerouted everything through manual toggles since the new lockdowns.
Sector 19's dead zone is shrinking, I got caught too close last week.
Patrols have sensors tuned for our old frequencies now.
I almost dumped my quad to avoid them—close call.
Used to be rhythm, now it's just adrenaline. Different vibe.
Feels like the city doesn't want us to breathe lately.
I miss when it was just about flying, not hiding.
Analog only. Digital gets flagged before you even plug in these days.
Used to run full race circuits with friends—we're all scattered post-blackout.
Since Directorate curfews, even the machine halls feel unsafe.
Patrols scan for signals, so I strip everything down pre-flight, no OSD, nothing traceable.
Last week, I was grounded for hours under a crate after sensors pinged.
Not much point in customizing—components are rationed and black market's risky.
I keep flying because it keeps my head clear, but it's not free anymore.
Feels like we're all being funneled into safe routines, no room for honest mistakes.
Sometimes flying is just remembering I can choose my own path, even if only for a few minutes.
